reviewText:
Bear with me as this is my first game review on Steam:

Pros:
- Great customization (Skills, Freestyle variability, Clothing, Stat allocation)
- Requires teamwork (Heavy)
- Crew matches (Like GvG in MMORPGs)
- Easy to pick up, Hard to master

Cons:
- Community can be toxic (Will explain more later)
- You can pay for stats
- Fluid gameplay relies heavily on latency (ping)

Freestyle2 is a great Multiplayer Online 3v3 Streetball game that pleases my thirst for basketball games.
It is very easy to pick up (You only use direction keys + 4 basic keys + 2 or 3 more for specific skills),
but hard to master.

It relies moderately on basketball knowledge, such as actual basketball tactics like Pick and Roll, which can be executed in the right situation. To win, you will have to try your best to fulfill your one of five (C, PF, SF, SG, PG) position's purpose.

Positions and their roles are generalized in FreeStyle2, although adventurous stat allocation may lead to fun and creative plays (like improving 3 pointers success rate on C or PFs).

C: Rebounding and blocking, setting up plays under the paint
PF: Similar to C, but takes an offensive role
SF: All-rounder (Dunk, rebound, middle jumper, 3s)
SG: Also an all-rounder with heavier emphasis on 3s
PG: Playmaker (Passing and loose ball grabbing)

Playing the position that fits you and doing it right comes with a great rewarding feeling.
Also, there are many team compositions which are strong, but you will run into hell lot of weird ones online (Triple Cs)

If you aren't good at what your position is supposed to be doing by Major (past level 11), you will most likely be dealt with offensive words, telling you that you suck and that you should quit.

The playerbase isn't large enough to have the greatest matchmaking system and tiers - and this is why sometimes you will face teams that will totally ♥♥♥♥ on your face. Knowing your position and having individual skills is very important in this game and when a single teammate is not pulling their own weight, it shows definitely.

I highly suggest trying each of the 5 positions before moving onto Major (level 11+)

You can pay for extra stats (btw you can also do this for free, but not as much).
Does it help? Yeah, I guess.
Does it win games? Maybe - it makes minimal difference.

Why is that?

Let's say a player purchased items and also obtained cards to improve his 3 pointers.
If you are guarding him perfectly, he won't score any 3 pointers.
If you don't and give him open shots on 3s, you should really blame yourself.

Teamwork (Strategy, Individual talent, knowing how each other reacts in certain situations) is much much much much holy freaking so much more important and impactful than stats.

Gamekiss will be adding controller support very soon, and I am so excited for that!

Give this game a try. If you like working as a team and enjoy basketball in general, you will love it!

reviewText:
I've been playing Freestyle for 7 long years. Since I was 12 years old, Freestyle has been my favorite game.
It has been with me throughout all my teenage years, and I don't regret a thing.

Ever since it first came out in 2006 (published by Activision), the game has had issues maintaining a good population due to lack of advertising and support from the foreign developers (JCE).

That's all hopefully going to change now that it has been released on Steam. It's a shame how we had to wait so many years for this because this is one of the most competitive games in the world.

Everybody who plays this game strives to ultimately be the best, and it's a team game so you have to find 2 other players who share the same mindset as you and want to be the best just as bad as you are.

A lot of this game consists of managing egos of not only your rivals, but your teammates also.
There is only one ball in the game of basketball, and scoring is only one part of it.
You have to have a good overall team that can not only score, but rebound, defend, block, steal, and pass at the right times.

This game is all about customization and making your player unique. There is a big item shop in the game that allows you to buy headgear,tops,bottoms, shoes, and accesories to make your baller look unique.

There are also Freestyles that allow you to change basic animations like dunks and shots so you can turn your simple one handed dunk in to a crazy 360 between the legs dunk!

Then you have your skills. Skills are new animations and upgrades you unlock through leveling your character.
Skills are the most important part of the game since they give really useful animations like diving for the ball or fading away.

When you first start the game and you go in to Rookies, you will be playing versus new players such as yourself who are also learning the game and it will be a cake walk for those who learn faster than others.

Beware though, there is a huge learning curve when you reach the big leagues (PRO Channel).
People do NOT like losing in Pros because it will result in their win % going down and the person that beat you having proof of them beating you.

I was never a guy to make many friends on this game, in fact I made a lot more enemies than I did friends and I am very hated but my advice to you new players is, make some friends before you reach Pros.

reviewText:
Bear in mind that this review comes from a person who used to play Freestyle 1 a lot of years ago. I've played in Thailand servers, in Gamekiss (NA) servers, in 4Game (Russian) servers and my country always had a big community in this game because we are big on basketball. There will be a lot of comparing

Before my rant, remember: I HATE BASKETBALL.
Yes, I hate basketball. I've played this game for so long (the Freestyle 1 version) even though I hate basketball. You know why? Because this game is super fun even if you don't know anything about basketball. There is constant action, it's super rewarding to block, rebound and when you hit a 3-pointer, it's the best feeling ever.

Freestyle 1 was actually rather bad.
It was full P2W, clothes that give attributes were all costing money, the OP moves that were difficult to block were all expensive and you HAD to buy them with real life money. There were serveral exploits like when you receive a pass, you get a speedboost. Exploiting that, you could always step back faster than your opponent and make yourself unblockable. Level system was awful, you only got your real position at level 15 and the grind to 45 (max level) was like the whole game. High level people could do anything and everything so you had to block them every time because they would hit every shot. You know why that was awful? That's right, the speed boost exploit.

Freestyle 2 possibly improves every mechanic that existsted in FSSB1.
Skills costs like 3k at the start, meanwhile you get like 50k points at the start by registering, eliminating the grinding element of the game.
Freestyles (Skills that only makes your shot/dunk different, making it harder to be blocked) can now be used only once or twice per game because you have to meet the requirements to do them. However, once you do them, it's garanteed points, so I think that's a nice touch.
You choose freestyles on your own, instead of them spinning in the exact same order for the whole game.
Music is constantly playing in game, making you feel in action. Also, the soundtrack makes you super pumped, while you can also configure it
FSSB1 Games were all the same: PFs/Cs rebound, pass it to SGs and they shoot 3points OR PFs just dunking and you can't block them because they have paid for the awesome almost unblockable dunks. In FSSB2, or at least in early stages of FSSB2, it won't be like this. SGs can be blocked easily, there are way more rebound patterns for rebounders to learn, etc.
Bigger skill variety
Can be played with a controller. I haven't tried it yet, but I think it might be really fun
Awesome rewarding system, making you feel progressing, most daily quests  aren't considered grinding and there are constant events. You also constantly get items and a lot of points, also making the game not P2W
EVEN IF YOU DON'T LIKE BASKETBALL, YOU WILL ENJOY THIS GAME

It's super rewarding. I watched a streamer play it with friends in front of 13k thousand viewers yesterday and he had a blast, meanwhile not even knowing that you can't shoot while you are getting defended by someone. He still had fun, I saw the excitement in his eyes meanwhile he was watching whether  the ball will go into the basket or not.  ALSO, IT'S SUPER FUN TO PLAY WITH FRIENDS

Even if you dislike basketball, dislike sports games like I do, you might still have a blast. It might still be super fun for you, or at least fun for 3-10 hours. You have nothing to lose, it's  free to play. Grab some friends, put your game pants and gunnars and go play it! This game is awesome and the devs definitely stepped up their game, adding new elements and improving  the old ones.

reviewText:
Having played this game for quite some time this is how I feel about it:

Positive:
+ It's fun: Seriously, the game is really fun.
+ Has a nice mixture of simplicity and complexity: The game is easy to get into, the controllers are kind of basic but it has a high skill cap, it's hard to master them.
+ Character Costumization: It's really nice.
+ The game has tons of features to keep you entertained: Bingo, My Ball, Freestyles, Challenges, etc.
+ It's rewarding to play: The achievement system combined with Bingo, My Ball, Freestyles, etc. makes you feel like a winner even when you're losing, so there's some reward in actually playing the game, even if you're not that good at it and just like playing it for the sake of having fun.
+ MVP: MVP rewards the player that contributes more for the team instead of the one that just scores all the time. Maybe it could be a bit more balanced, but it's nice to see the game reward team play.

Ofcourse there are negative points too.

Negative:
- Paying actually makes you better: Or atleast makes you seem like you are. Paid characters, like Ginger, for example, WILL punish you if you make a mistake, they are deadly because of the bonus they are given. Maybe in higher levels of gameplay that becomes less noticeable, but in lower levels it's really noticeable, they barely miss. And also there are skill slots unlockable by paying, and that gives more options to people that pay to unlock them, giving them an advantage over free plays. I'll put this on capslock: THE GAME IS NOT FULLY PAY TO WIN. That's not what I'm saying here! What I'm saying is the feeling that I got, that if you're a free player and paying against a paid character in a similar player skill level it's more likeable that he will easily punish your mistakes thanks to the character he has than you are likely to punish is, since you don't have as much stats and special bonus as he has.
- Matchmaking is... weird: I dont know how matchmaking works on this game, but more than a few times I got to play against players that you could see by the skills they were using that they were atleast 10 levels above the players on my team. And I also felt the reverse on some games, that I was being matched with people levels below. Most of the time it felt fine, but I think it was like 80/20, so I thought it would be worth to mention.
- Menus: Menus can be a bit confusing for newer players, since they are presented with a huge BOOM of stuff.
- Clarity: The game isn't very clear on some stuff. For example, I had to go google for quite a bit of time why I couldn't level any stat after putting 5 points into it and the game doesn't tell you what keys to use on your controller, so even if it supports it, it's kind of better to play on the keyboard. That kind of stuff.

Overall it's a good and fun game. I recommend it, even if you don't like basketball that much, give it a shot and try to bring your friends to play it with you, only makes it more fun. I'm curious to see the game evolve, since It's kind of new, from what I've read.

This is the same FreeStyle Street Basketball MMO under new management with a re-touched coat of paint and 5-10 extra ways to get you to spend money on items you don't actually want.

Pros:
-Fresh, vibrant artstyle
-Arcade style gameplay
-Decent Customization options
-Well-organized lobbies ranked by skill level
-Bot support
-Clan support

Cons:
-Annoying community
-Sketchy connection issues (On my first FSBB2 session, I was dropped from a game loading screen no less than 7 times in a row)
-Puzzling sound direction (I don't necessarily mind the Korean rap, but the voice acting leaves a bit to be desired)
-Too many unnecessary features. Booster cards, gachapon-style power-ups, robots that shout nice things and return balls for you after each shot in practice, a post-game breakdown that pats you on the back and lets you pick a mystery card: basically, every smoke-and-mirrors parlor trick mobile game designers have tried to implement into one gaudy, bedazzled cardboard box.

In short: yes, I found it fun. I found it fun the last time I played the same game 5 years ago. There isn't enough improvement here for me to specifically recommend the game to any of my friends, especially not the ones who abandoned the game with me last time. I was expecting something different out of a sequel to a game that already had glaring flaws regarding netcode and connection issues, honestly. Daily Login bonuses and fake tickets for electronic roulette prizes won't cover up the few issues that still seem to exist.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
It's fun for a bit and the game runs pretty well. I only experience small amounts of latency issues that really changed the tide of the match but it was rare.

My true gripe with the game is the balancing as you level up, not so much the balance once you're at the top of level and have unlocked all the skills and attributes. During the first few levels on the beginner server, the game is fun but it's ruined by ball hogs and people who don't understand the sport or the game at all. I think out of 50+ Matches I had in the beginner server, very very few of the matches were competitive. Either your team stomped the other team or your team got stomped because you were paired up with people who didnt understand the fundamentals to the game (would try to do half court shots with a C, SG's would just stay under the rim for a rebound) But the games that were closer in score were actually really fun. Once you're fresh out of the beginner server, thats when the game gets even worse, you still have people who don't understand the game at all but not only that, you are matched up against people who have unlocked very strong skills that you don't have access to until you grind out several dozen matches. These skills literally make the player exponentionally overpowered compared to the skills you have when you are a fresh level 12 (Alley-Oop spam, Back Step dribble, etc.) So you have to endure through these matches because more often then not, you will be paired up with people still learning the game and have no idea how to play against teams that are already overpowered so they resort to afk exp farming. That alone is abused like heck, people just matches just to afk and get the match experience because they know they will most likely lose to higher level players.

I'd love to recommend the game because it can be really fun, but it just gets worse until you get to much higher level and everyone balances out and the game becomes more skill based. But enduring the grind of the early levels coupled with players that don't understand the game and the afk farm, just ruins it all for me.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
When I saw this, I was hoping for a competent street basketball game with some paid character customizations and some kinda gross paid stat boosts. What I found instead was a poorly translated storefront with a terrible basketball game attached.

Best I can tell, you are forced to control your character with the keyboard rather than a gamepad, which seems an odd choice for a basketball game. The rules of the game (both in terms of the rules in the rulebook and the way basketball works) are implemented very simplisticly. For example, if you want to block a shot, You'll need to be sure you're in front of the shooting player. It's literally impossible to block a short from the side or from behind.

It feels like a board game implementation of basketball, and, as much as I like board games, the beauty of video games is that the game can juggle as many rules and variables as you can throw at it. Board games have to be simplified because people have to manage all those rules themselves. For a game as dynamic as basketball, this implementation doesn't create a very satisfying experience.

The UI is ridiculous. Every screen has dozens of buttons labeled mostly with cryptic icons. As a new player, you'll be given several reward items after logging in, but you'll have no idea what they are or why you would want them. In this way, the game is extremely hostile to new players.

If there is any fun to be had in this game, it's well hidden behind a smokescreen of odd design decisions and mechanisms designed to get you to give them money.

Well it was really fun and refreshing at first. Gameplay is good and fun, and even if you got 1 bad player on your team, no game is lost. Also the Presentation is cool and even playing Defence is rewarding.
I was fed up with NBA2k15s streetball mode, because it was lagging so hard it was unplayable. This game felt very direct and no lags at all. That part was really well done.

But that said ... what ruins my experience after over 24h ingame is the Pay2Win which is absolutely over the top.
If you play with the normal characters vs. normal characters, it is all fun and fair. I also don't mind paying for faster leveling or extra gear, not even for some additional skillslots and other minor advantages.

What absolutely kills the game are the special purchaseable characters. While there are some that only grant a minor advantage like a small stats boost in a certain stat, there are some that just can't be beaten with the free chars, unless the other player is a total noob.

As an example, playing as Center, it is impossible to get rebounds vs. some pay-centers, even with the perfect timing.  If you walk into them they just push you away automatically and you stumble backwards, for example. So no chance of even getting close to the hoop.

Also there are chars that grant you a +40 stats boost that you can assign as you wish. And that is A LOT!
So if you level up, you get +2 stats per level. so These speciial chars have a 20 level advantage over you statswise. This just can not be beaten. It is like playing a level 1 vs. level 20 char ... or 10 vs. 30 and so on.
This is just very very frustrating and unfair.

I really like the game, but I do not see a point in spending 10 bucks on chars I don't want to play because the P2W system forces me to. And then ... I don't think it is entertaining pounding normal chars with my pay chars, because they have no chance. There is no challenge in that and it would be unrewarding and boring. At least for me.

So one good thing is, the game offers a newby channel. There is a normalchannel for levels 1-11 and a newby channel 1-11. You can only get into the newby channel if you did not level a char past level 11.
While I was in there, it was the most fun and the best times. Why, because almost noone had those imba chars there.

once you move to the normal channel or past level 12 ... you encounter a pay char in what feels like 2/3 of the games. If you are lucky" you get that guy/gal on your team ... easy mode. If you are even unluckyer

I'm just going to go straight into it. I've put in about 30 or so hours into this game and I have enjoyed my time spent with it for the most part.

Freestyle 2 is a basketball game that is published by Joycity and hosted by Gamekiss. The game is run on a free 2 play model and while that may raise red flags for some, I've found it to be very fun and fair. After logging in, you are able to pick from a couple of classes. Small Forward, Point Forward, Center, Shot Guard, etc. After choosing a class, you are shown a list of different characters, that are really just chosen based on your preferred look or style. The game doesn't really offer any body customization like skin color, hair, eyes. But you can purchase different clothes, wigs, etc in the game shop. (They actually have a decent selection for the ingame free points that can be earned through playing.)

~Gameplay~
I've found the mechanics of this game to be enjoyable, they all work how I'd expect. The controls definately took some getting used to. It's been a long time since I've used my keyboads directional keys.

The A button is to drive dribble, which consumes stamina and allows you to dash with the ball to pass your opponent.

S is to pass or steal

D is to shoot or block

W is to guard or post up. (Moving towards the basket with ball in a slower and more defensive motion.

I've found that it's a little bit harder to play defense than offense, but it all works well and feels really good when you dunk on an oppenent and he/she is slammed back down.

Your character(s) also have stats and level up. Level 50 is the max and the progression can be a bit slow after level 30. You put points into various attributes like 3 pt, layup, middle shot, speed, stamina, etc. The stats feel somewhat minor and it take's a bit to really notice a big difference. You can also buy skills and this opens up the game to a lot more, making it faster and way more interesting. One of the skills I received allows me to drive dribble back and forth to really shake up my opponents.

I find the gameplay extremely enjoyable and for that alone, I can reccommend this game to just about anyone especcially if you have friends, but we will get to that.

~Graphics~
The game looks nice. It's a very simple cel shaded style and it runs pretty well on most low end computers that I've played on as well.  If you turn up the game to high/medium, you may notice the game having a blurry effect on the characters. I personally didn't like this effect and found the game to look better on low. You only have preset graphic selections of low, medium, and high, so I found no way to turn it off. Speaking of which, I should probably talk about the options menu a bit more.

You cannot rebind your keys for drive dribble, pass, shoot, steal, or your movement. I found that to be a bit silly in a pc only game. Also no controller support, but they offer a guide on the site's forums that is stickied and it explains how to use a controller. This is still not a good thing in my opinion and hopefully they will add more options in the future, but I don't see it happening.


~Sound~
The music is different to say the least. It's like k pop mixed with rap. I personally liked it and at times found it hilarious, but after a while I got tired of hearing the same tracks over and over again and listened to some of my own music.


~Community~

Disclaimer: Another persons experience may differ from mine.

So the community is pretty small, but you should not have an issue finding any games. Though, I must reccommend playing with friends. Usually in a small community, you would expect players to be a bit more tight-knit, but that is far from the case. There are a lot of people that say the trash talking is just apart of the game. I can agree some what with that, but that isn't where my problem with the community really comes from.

You will experience more ♥♥♥♥ talking from fellow team mates. Players will berate you if you just get unlucky and miss a shot. You may see people go into all chat and call there own teammates noobs, because they are losing the game. (You lose nothing important by losing a game except your winrate and you still recieve the same exp and points for losing or winning.)

Edit: I can understand someone not wanting to see their win ratio lowered. I've done quite a bit of competitive gaming and sometimes communities will judge based on your win ratio and not your actual skill. It's just the way of the world, unfortunately.

I have to reccomend that you play this game with friends, because it is an extremely good time with people you know, win or lose.

~Cash shop pay to win or not?~
I've played up to level 50 so far and have not experienced any real need to pay. Though there are things to pay for if you want to min max. There are cards that can be found with either luck or in a gachapon that boost your stats by a couple of points and then can be upgraded further. Some may want to find the best versions of those cards that upgrade the stats they want. There are also some cash only cosmetics to purchase, but no outfits have an expiration date and as I've said earlier, I was able to find a decent selection for points and they didn't take very long to buy.

You can pay for extra skill slots and that seems to be the most pay 2 win aspect, but from what I've read, you can make a  good character without ever paying.

There are also exp boosts and such for conveniece and I've found the model to be fair and I don't think there is anything wrong with the system.

~Conclusion~

I can definitely reccommend this game to just about anyone, especially if you have friends to play with. You will have an easier time with the community if you solo que at a lower level, but once you get into the higher leveled games, you will see a lot of hostility from your own teammates. Other wise, this is probably one of the best basketball games I've ever played. It runs well and does everything I'd expect from it.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar

6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Well this game is pretty good but...

There are some issues. It being focused on Team play mainly is pretty good but you know, you get those ball hogs that don't pass when you're open... facepalm. Anyway this game is good with 2 other friends, other than that there isn't more problems, its a great and fun game, pretty grind fested BUT though it might be grindy its still very enjoyable and not that boring. The only MASSIVE issue I have other than the team mates which isn't so bad is the lag. And its pretty dang big. I live in Australia so I have to play on the Asian servers since I get the best ping. I thought having 170 ping was good, nope. If you have over like 80 ping you can barely do good. Well I am not to sure about under 100 ping but over 100 its horrible. You get blocked on your shot all the time, even if you're open for a split second, INSTANT block EVEN THOUGH you shouldn't of been blocked. Same goes for rebounding, person has better ping they'll get it.

So in the end its a great game but the ping and teammates is the only horrible part. PLEASE GET AN OCEANIC SERVER!

reviewText:
Product received for free

I have put a lot, and I mean A LOT of time into this game, I've been playing it for over a year so I think I've got enough knowledge about this game to finally review/talk it.

First, I would like to say that I have not spent a single penny on this game, not because I don't want to support it, but because I'm still a student with no job, so this will all be how it goes from a £0 experience.

Now, this game is really fun, it has 3 a side street basketball where you play with people online, you can choose one of 8 positions (5 main ones plus 3 special positions which makes the game a lot more fun) I have dabbled in each class, the best for me being a Short Forward and a Swing Man.

It has a lot of skills in the game, each class getting a different set depending on their role, but also allowing them to extend what they can do, for example, my main SF is also really good at passing and assisting like a Point Guard. You unlock these as you level up your separate characters, skills do not transfer between characters so every time you make a new one it will be like starting over again. Something else that doesn't go between characters is your inventory (Unless it's a character coupon) so everything you get with a character can't be used with another, which is really good as you can't make a new character but give them clothes or cards that a level 50 (Max level) character would use.

What does go between characters is points and money (Points being things you get after a game and money being what you buy with real money) so you may be able to buy a skill (which use regular points) as soon as you unlock it instead of having to wait for you to get more money. What also is between characters would be sponsors (Being exp, points and VIP) which gives you a boost in what you get after a match. You can get these by either buying them or getting them dropped through one of the many events that take place.

The main downside to this game is that I live in England but my friend who I play with lives in America, meaning that if we decide to play together, one of us will have to sacrifice some ping to go to the other server, luckily the account goes between severs so I can play in Europe server with my characters while not playing with my friend and level them up.

All in all, this game is really fun and I recommend it to anyone that wants a basketball game to play with friends but doesn’t have a lot of money, but you can always spend money if you want. You can always win if you are good enough, so just practice and have fun!
